titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VII. I wrote a note to Mr del Real, proposing to receive him at 3. O’Clock this day at Craven Street. Walked in to London in two hours and 31 minutes, leaving orders for the Carriage to come with George, and to be at the Office, at a quarter past six. On arriving in town, I found a Letter, (printed) from Mr Francis Freeling, Secretary of the Post-Office, returning me two Letters which had been sent to the foreign Post-Office, without payment of the Postage. One of them was to Mr Harris at St: Petersburg, which had been opened; the other was to Mr Simpson the Consul at Morocco, which having been sent at the same time, under the same Seal, and superscribed in the same hand (Mr Smith’s) was by special favour sent back with the Seal unbroken— The omission to pay the Postage, had been an accidental inattention. This is the second time that such an accident has happened, and it has been fortunate that the Letters opened were of no importance— A Letter from Henry Nodin and Co. requesting a Passport from me, for a Mr Richard Baxter, a British Subject, to go to the United States— I desired Mr Smith to inform the person applying in this case, that no Passport was necessary or proper for me to give to a British Subject.— From the frequency of such applications to me, I incline strongly to the belief that they do at the Alien-Office, make use of their powers over aliens, to obstruct the departure of British Subjects, by suffering them at least to believe, that they must have Passports to go to America— A Letter from Mr G. M. Woolsey at Liverpool, complaining that an entry had been refused by the Collector of the Customs there, to certain tobacco, because the Collector at Richmond had certified that the Master of the vessel in which it was ship, had been qualified, to the Manifest; instead of saying that he had been sworn to it. The Act of Parliament requiring that the Manifest should be sworn to, at the place of shipment. The Master had taken an Oath, before a Magistrate at Liverpool, that he had
sworn to his Manifest, at Richmond; not withstanding which, the Collector at Liverpool, refused to allow the entry of the tobacco. I immediately addressed a Note to Lord Castlereagh, on the subject, and answered Mr Woolsey’s Letter.— It was only a quarter before seven, when the Carriage with George arrived, and I was afraid of being belated at the dinner— Just then came in a Frenchman named Thibert, who is about publishing a new French Grammar, and has made repeated applications to obtain my subscription or patronage, which I have as often declined; having been surfeited with new Systems of French Grammar— He enquired for Mr Smith—who was gone out to dinner— I left him with George to wait for Smith—dressed and went immediately to St: James’s Palace, to the Duke of Clarence’s Apartments; and dined with the Prince of Saxe-Coburg. 30 [symbols] All the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers were there— The Archbishop of York, Bishop of London; Marquis of Cholmondeley the Lord Steward, Lord George Beresford, Mr: Chester, and Coll: Hardenbrock, the Prince’s Cavaller, or Gentleman— The Prince is a tall, well formed, handsome man, modest and reserved in his deportment, wearing as easily as could be expected the new and extraordinary fortune that has befallen him.— The transition from the condition of a third Son, to a petty German Prince, whose whole dominions scarcely surpass the extent of an English manor; and from the rank of a Captain of Cavalry in the Russian service, to the office of husband to the presumptive heiress of the British Realms, is one of those vicissitudes in human life, which every head would not be of strength to bear— The Prince has nothing of arrogance in his manner— He shews nothing of an elated Spirit— But there is a point of view from which a proud Spirit, with a delicate sense of honour must perceive something to discolour at least in part the flattering complexion of his present state— There is an apparent consciousness of this nature in his manners, which though different from the perfect ease of greatness familiar with itself, is neither unnatural nor absolutely unbecoming. He was polite and attentive to all his company, and especially to the German Ministers, of whom there were six present. He spoke a few words to me in English; enquired how long I had been in this Country, and observed that he spoke English very imperfectly himself, but hoped to acquire it soon— There was a crowd of People collected in Stable yard, before the windows of the chamber in which the Company were received before dinner.— They shouted occasionally to make him shew himself, and he went out once or twice on the balcony to be seen; stood two or three minutes and then came in again. I was luckily not the latest person that arrived; Count Beroldingen the Minister of Wurtemberg came a few minutes after me— The dinner was then immediately announced— There was turtle Soup, Venison and Strawberries; with other dishes more in Season— The wines, were merely good. I sat between the Danish Minister Mr Bourke, and the Archbishop of York, whom I found very ready in conversation, and very agreeable. He mentioned several particulars of the present situation of the king; being one of the Queen’s Council, for the guardianship of his Person— He has been for nearly five years confined to two or three Chambers in Windsor Castle— His bodily health is good— His appetite regular, and the Archbishop says he considers him, as the best life, of his age in the kingdom. He is blind, but immediately recognizes by the voice every person whom he has known. His principal amusement is music— Playing upon a bad Piano, which he has in one of his chambers. He is attentive to the neatness of his person, to great excess— He had for sometime a long white beard, but is now regularly shaved— The Archbishop spoke slightingly of the form of Prayer, now used in the Churches for the king’s recovery, which he said you must read almost through before you could discover what it was about. But he said when it had been drawn up and prescribed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, it had been expected that the king’s illness would last only a few weeks— The prayer is indeed neither sense nor grammar— Nor can any one discover from it, what it is about— It implores that God would restore the king to his family and his People—and then puts the case whether this great calamity, with which we are afflicted shall be removed or still suspended over us— The Archbishop spoke of the Society for the propagation of the gospel, and of the Bible Society— Of his Office as Archbishop, and his Office as Lord High Almoner, in which capacity, and not in the other, he is to be present at the marriage to-morrow— He told us that the sum which he has to distribute as Lord High Almoner, is about £2400 a year; two thirds of which was distributed in small pensions to poor widows; which he had limited to the widows of Officers in the army or navy or of Clergymen— The rest was given out in silver pieces of one, two three and four penny silver pieces, which were coined at the mint for that single purpose— He shewed us several of the four penny pieces which he had in his pocket— The dinner was of about two hours duration, and the company returned to the Drawing Room to Coffee for about a Quarter of an hour. And all retired at once before ten O’Clock— I went to Craven-Street, changed my Dress; and then called at Mr Sanders’s lodgings for George— Mr Sanders came out and urged me so strongly to go in and join his party for a short time that I could not refuse— Mr Smith was there, a company of seven or eight young men: part of them at Cards, and the rest in Conversation— Between eleven and twelve, a handsome Supper was served— It was near one in the morning when we came away, and between two and three when we reached home— We came back by Acton road.

2. IX. Marriage of the Princess Charlotte of Wales.— The dissipation of yesterday, and that of this day, disqualified me for any serious occupation: and I could write nothing but an answer to the invitation from the Fishmonger’s Company to dine with them at their Hall on the 23d of this month— At 3 in the afternoon I left home, and walked, until the Carriage with Mrs Adams, George, and Lucy overtook me, a mile beyond Acton. we went into London, to Mr and Mrs King’s Lodgings at N. 60 Conduit Street— I walked down to Craven-Street, to enquire if we could have lodgings there for the Night; but Mr Smith was not there— I returned to Mr King’s, where we dined— And at Mr and Mrs King’s invitation we accepted a lodging there. Just at eight o’Clock we went to Carleton House, which we reached without difficulty; although the Streets from Picadilly, and particularly Pall-Mall, were thronged with immense Crowds of People— The company to be present at the nuptial Ceremony were collecting until about nine O’Clock in an Apartment called the crimson Room. There were perhaps two hundred persons present— The Royal Family—the Cabinet Ministers, the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers—The Household Officers—and all their Ladies—The Archbishops of Canterbury and York—And the Bishops of London and Salisbury— About nine the Queen and Princesses came in—followed by the Prince Regent, and soon afterwards by the parties to be married— The Service was read remarkably well, by the Archbishop of Canterbury, and the responses were very distinctly and audibly made by the Prince and Princess— After the Ceremony they both kneeled to the Prince Regent, and to the Queen— They immediately afterwards went away, in a Travelling Chariot, to the Duke of York’s Country Seat at Oatlands; about twenty miles from London, where they are to pass a week or ten days. The Queen and the rest of the company remained.— And about an hour after the ceremony was over the Queen and the Prince Regent walked
round the Circle, after which the Queen retired, to a party at Cards in another Apartment.— There were refreshments served at a Side Board.— Cold Sandwiches—Wedding Cake—Limonade, Orange-water—Wines, and Ardent Spirits— Prince Esterhazy the father took with some effort of complacency, a glass of Cherry-Brandy. The Dukes of York, Clarence, and Kent were there; the Duchess of York—the Princesses Augusta, Elizabeth, and Mary, and Princess Sophia of Gloucester— But neither the Duke or Duchess of Cumberland, the Duke of Sussex, or the Duke of Gloucester. The heat of the rooms was almost insupportable. The Queen went away about Midnight; after which it was allowable for the rest of the Company to depart.— We went to Mr and Mrs King’s Lodgings, where we found Mr Bibby, Mr Gracie, and our Son George— He went to lodge with Mr Smith at Craven-Street; and it was between one and two in the Morning when we retired to bed.

3. VIII:30. We had just breakfasted, when George came from Craven Street, and brought me several Letters— 31 [symbols] Two of 3. & 5. April from Mr Simpson the American Consul at Tangier; being only a duplicate of the Letter which I had already received and answered; with a repetition of the request that I would authorize the Brothers Baring to pay the Bills that he had drawn upon them— One from Edward Perkins, the Vice-Consul at Bristol, respecting the Brig Helen, the vessel, stranded in Cardigan-Bay; and enclosing a Letter to him, from her Captain, Fitzgerald, to justify himself from the charge of having wilfully run her ashore— One from George and James Abel, asking an interview with me, relative to the indirect Trade to India in American Vessels; concerning which they have written to me before. One from Mr George Boyd at Washington of 17. March—about a contract which he is desirous of making to supply the Government of the United States with 10.000 french muskets; and concerning which he wishes me to make enquiries— And one from Mr Fox, the Consul at Falmouth, relating to the Ship Baltimore and her Seamen. I walked immediately down to the Office in Craven Street; and soon after came in a Mrwho arrived yesterday from New-York— He brought me three despatches from the Secretary of State— Two of March 9. respecting the William and Mary, taken at Cadix, about which I have already been much occupied; and respecting another Mary and Cargo, taken and condemned in the Island of Jamaica— And one of 19. March. instructing me to apply to this Government, for permission to export Rollers for the use of the Mint of the United States. There was also a file of National Intelligencers from the beginning of the year, to the 19th. of March—and an enclosed Letter from Mr Wilson Cary Nicholas, the Governor of Virginia, requesting me to enquire, and let him know upon what terms, a civil Engineer, capable of designing and superintending improvements of rivers, roads and Canals, could be engaged to go to Virginia, to prosecute works of that kind, which the Legislature of that Commonwealth at their late Session, have provided funds, for commencing and carrying on— I enquired of Mrwhether Mr Bagot and his family had arrived in the United States, before he sailed— He said he had; and had been presented to the President— I had met at Carleton House last Evening, Mrs: Wellesley-Pole, Mrs Bagot’s Mother, who was extremely anxious at not having heard of her arrival— She had earnestly desired me, if I should hear of their arrival, to give her notice of it; which I had promised; and assured her it should be within ten days; and I hoped within three— Mrs Adams came with the Carriage at two O’Clock— We went immediately to Mrs Wellesley-Pole’s house— She was just gone out to see her daughter, Lady Fitzroy Somerset— We left cards, and I directed her Servant who came to the door, to inform her that I had called to tell her of the safe arrival of Mr Bagot and his family at Washington— 1 [symbols] We then went, and had our names written at Camelford House, for the Prince and Princess of Saxe-Coburg, at Buckingham House for the Queen; and at Carleton House for the Prince Regent— It was for this formality that we had remained in town over Night. Mr Chester had told me that it would be a proper mark of attention. As I went into the Antichamber at Carleton House to write our names, I found Lord Walpole there upon the same business. I had not seen him since I left St: Petersburg— I spoke to him, and as he appeared not to recognize me, mentioned my name— He said without moving a muscle of his face—“you’ve grown fatter”; and having written his name, went out, without making me any salutation— As he had been introduced to me at St: Petersburg, at his own request while our two Countries were at War; and as he had always been very civil, and sociable when we met there, I was surprized at his conduct now; and know not how to account for it, unless from a remnant of ill humour, from certain mortifications, which he experienced at St: Petersburg after I came away, before the close of our War. Harris often wrote me that Lord Walpole was extremely discourteous to him, and this sulky insolence may be a sequel of the same pettish temper— We returned to Craven Street; and just as we were leaving it to return home, Mrs King called, with an acquaintance of hers, a Mrs Porter, a Scotch Lady; to pay Mrs Adams a visit. She stayed only a few minutes, and invited us to dine with her next Thursday. We then came home, by the way of Brook Green where there has been these three days a Fair—the remnant of which only we saw; and to disadvantage, as there was a cold rain almost the whole day— I had seen the preparations for this Fair, and crowds of People going to it, and many May-day Garlands when I walked into London, the day before Yesterday.— We reached home just before dinner time; and I found a Note from Mr S. F. Waddington; with a hint of information, and a promise of more in future— An invitation from Count & Countess Lieven
to Mrs Adams and me, to dine with them next Tuesday: and one from the Countess, to attend her Evening party next Sunday— We had both engaged last Evening to dine next Tuesday with Mr and Mrs Bourke— There was also a Letter from Mr Grubb, enclosing one from a Major General Irenée Amelot de la Croix, Baron Van den Boegard, from Amsterdam— A Letter for Coll: Irenee Amelot de la Croix, addressed to my care, had been laying at the Office, ever since last September; and I knew not who it was for, I how it came thus directed— He gives the explanation having been in America, an Aid de Camp of Genl: Moreau; and coming to Europe, he was advised by Mr G. Blake, to have his Letters addressed to my care. He asks me to deliver any such that I may have received, to a Mr Van Oven, who left his Letter, and a Card with his own address, with Mr Grubb.

4. VIII. The occupations and dissipations of the last days, with the multitude of objects to which the Letters received have called at once my attention have almost disqualified me for writing; and I barely finished this day a Letter to the Secretary of State; begun four days ago— John and Charles came home from School— Mrs Adams and I went soon after Noon to London— I had requested Mr Smith Yesterday, to answer the Note from Messrs: G. & J. Abel, and inform them that I would see them at 2— O’Clock this day at my Office. A person belonging to their house came, with the Captain of the American vessel which they wish to clear out for a British Port in India— They came to enquire what had been done, and what was the Prospect on the subject. I told them that I had spoken and written to Lord Castlereagh, and had a Conversation with Mr Robinson concerning it— I was promised it should be satisfactorily arranged, and when I received further information would give them immediate notice— Mr del Real’s interpreter had called at the Office on Wednesday, the day that I had appointed to meet him, to say that as he was now residing in the Country, a few miles from town, he could not receive my Note in time to meet me that day. The interpreter had requested that I would name another; and I had mentioned this day at three O’Clock— The interpreter came at the time; somewhat anxious that Mr del Real himself did not appear— I told him that I would see Mr del Real, if it should suit his convenience next Tuesday, at the same hour— A French Officer came to enquire if I could procure a passage for him to the United States. Mrs Adams, Mr J. A. Smith and I, dined at Mr Murdoch’s at Gould Square Tower Hill, the same house where I often dined with him in 1796 and 1797 Mr Harrison Gray, Mr G. Joy, Mr G. Claggett, Mr and Mrs Kemble and Mr and Mrs Keimer were of the Company— On our return we left Mr Smith at Craven Street; and reached home; about one in the Morning— I received a Note from Lord Castlereagh; dated 27. April; in answer to mine with which I sent the Documents relating to the Sales of Slaves taken from the United States by British Officers in the late War.

5. VIII:30. Attended Church this Morning— Prayers for the third Sunday after Easter were read by Mr Millman, and the Sermon was preached by Mr Elmsley from 1. Peter II.12.—“that, whereas they speak against you as evil-doers, they may by your good works, which they shall behold, glorify God, in the day of visitation.”—an ingenious, learned, and charitable discourse— I answered a Letter from J. Phillips the projector of a new system of sailing; and the rest of the day was engaged in making a draft of a reply to Lord Castlereagh’s Note received yesterday— After dinner our Sons John and Charles returned to School— I was unwell and so thoroughly weary of the laborious idleness of the last week, that I remained at home— My wife took Lucy with her and went to Countess Lieven’s evening party.

6. IX. Mrs Adams came home from Countess Lieven’s Evening party, between two and three O’Clock this Morning— I am not yet able to settle into steady and close application to business— I wrote a short Letter to my father; and then engaged upon the draft of my reply to Lord Castlereagh’s note about the sale of the Slaves. He sent me with the Note a printed Act of Parliament of 25. March 1807, for the abolition of the Slave-Trade, and an order in Council of 16 March 1808, for carrying it into Execution— The Examination of these documents, makes it necessary to lengthen my reply. New reflections rise as I write, and my first draft of a Note will be little better than a Chaos to be afterwards methodized into form. While I was writing and meditating upon it, the hour of dinner imperceptibly stole upon me, and I found barely time for a walk to Ealing & Gunnersbury. My Butler Peter Pio, left us finally this morning; and went to the Middlesex Hospital where he has obtained admission— His complaint appears to be merely hypocondriac.

7. VI:30. Wrote this morning further upon the Draft to Lord Castlereagh, which I was however soon obliged to leave, to go to town. I walked to the Office in Craven Street, at a slow pace in 2 hours and 45 minutes; with a sprinkling of rain nearly half the way— I found there several visitors, and a large budget of Letters— Mr M. C. Paterson of New-York, brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Dr Mason of New-York, whom I saw once, several years ago, at Boston— Mr Paterson came from America, with Mr J. A. Smith, and has been spending the Winter at Edinburgh The two Mr: White’s came in just after I reached the Office, and were followed a few minutes after, by Mr del Real, and his interpreter. After waiting until they were gone, and Mr Smith had taken off Paterson, Mr del Real informed me that he had written several Letters and Memorials to Lord Castlereagh, to which he had received no answer— That he was desirous of obtaining an interview with him, to request an answer; that he might know upon what to rely, in relation to his official situation— He rather intimated than positively expressed the wish that I would introduce him to Lord Castlereagh; and asked if I could indicate any means by which he could obtain access to him— I told him that I was fully disposed to render him any service in my power; but he would recollect the conversation which had lately passed between us; in which we had agreed in opinion, that any extraordinary interest, shewn on the part of the United States towards the South-Americans, would unavoidably indispose in the same degree the British Government against them— The policy of the British Government hitherto decisively is not to acknowledge the Independence of the South Americans— Knowing this, I had neither officially nor individually such a state of personal Relations with Lord Castlereagh, as would warrant me in assuming the Liberty of introducing del Real to him; nor was it in my power to point out to him any other channel, through which he might obtain such an Introduction— I knew of no more favourable prospect, of success than by a
Note to Lord Castlereagh, explicitly asking for an Audience or an answer.— He said that he was unwilling to push on to extremities at once. That soon after his arrival here, he had seen Mr Vansittart the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who had then made no difficulty to receive him— He had told him that the British Government had ordered their naval Commanders to respect the flag of the South-Americans. Their vessels would be admitted into the British Ports, and the commerce of British subjects with them would be allowed— But that their Government could not be acknowledged— I told him that he must expect to find the British Government just at this time colder and more averse to an acknowledgment than they were— The fall of Carthagena, and the late successes of the royal party in Mexico, and in Peru, had very much shaken the opinions of People in Europe, generally as to the final success of the Insurgents. Perhaps the impression of those Events had been much greater than was warranted by their importance— I knew that such had been the effect of similar events, during the War of our Revolution. I believed he would find it better to wait until some more favourable turn to the Independent cause should take place, than to press for an answer now. He acquiesced in this opinion and left me— The Letters were—from A. Glennie Son and Co:—forwarding one from Moses Kempton junr: of Philadelphia, with a multitude of documents enclosed; all relating to a vessel and Cargo of his, seized and condemned at Jamaica; unjustly as he says, and he has applied for the interference of the American Government in behalf of his claim— He sends among the papers a Letter from Mr Monroe to Mr Sergeant (a member of Congress from Pennsylvania[)], promising that I shall be instructed to interpose. I had not time this day to read the documents through—from E. Perkins, Vice Consul at Bristol, with another bundle of Papers; letters and depositions, relating to Captain Fitzgerald and his Brig Helen; stranded on the Coast of Cardigan last December— The charge against him of having wilfully run her aground, appears to have been false and malicious— From James Holmes formerly Consul of the United States at Newry in Ireland, enclosing two Accounts for expences to relieve destitute American Seamen; which accounts Mr Maury had informed him I am authorized to settle. He complains of having heard that a Mr Luke has been appointed Consul of the U.S. at Belfast, though he himself was willing to have been reappointed Consul at Newry— From Alfred Fox, son of the Consul at Falmouth, and from Gustavus M. Ware a Seaman belonging to the ship Baltimore— Both these Letters relating to the extraordinary case of that ship, abandoned at sea by her Captain and Crew, and brought into Falmouth by ten men belonging to a British Packet— I answered them both— From J. Pitcairn at Hamburg— He has procured the copy of Bode’s Uranographia, to be sent to President Kirkland for the use of the Observatory at Harvard University; and promises that it shall be sent to Boston by the first trusty opportunity.— From one John M’Lellan of Hamilton, Scotland, about an Estate in America, of which he, with his wife and her Sisters, claim to be the heirs— 4 [symbols] From L & Learned enclosing a Letter for Mr Russell at Stockholm, from America— And From Mr Hamilton, Under Secretary of State, giving notice that the exequatur of Mr Ingraham’s Commission as Consul at Plymouth is ready to be delivered— Soon after six O’Clock Mrs Adams came to the Office— We dined at the Danish Minster, Mr Bourke’s— Baron Jacobi-Kloest, Count Beroldingen and Mr Pfeffel, The two Counts Bentheim, Countess Rumford (the widow) a Miss Baring, Baron Just, the Saxon Minister, and the French General Flahaut formed the company— After dinner, General Sebastiani came in— The dinner was elegant, with several rare importations from France— After dinner, two Card Tables were made up— I played whist with Madame Bourke, the youngest Count Bentheim, and Baron Just; until near Midnight— We came home by the Acton road; about two in the Morning.

8. VIII:45. Confined the whole day to the house, by Rain— The draft of the Note to Lord Castlereagh still engaged me exclusively. The morning Post, brought me a note from Mr Grubb, enclosing a long Letter from Mr Sumter, our Minister at the Brazils; dated 4. Feby: last— He mentions sending at the same time a paper of seeds for a Mr Salisbury at Brompton; but the seeds did not come— By the Evening Post we received Letters from my father, mother and brother to all the family; dated from the 20th. to the 28th. of March— Also a Letter to me from C. E. A. Schwabe, foreign Secretary to the British and foreign School Society, requesting my attendance at the General Meeting of the Institution to be held at the London Tavern Bishopsgate Street next Monday the 13th instant at 12 O’Clock— I declined a similar invitation to the meeting in Novr. a Platform ticket for myself, and two other tickets of admission each for a Lady and Gentleman were enclosed in Mr Schwabe’s Letter.

9. VI:30. Finished the draft of the Note to Lord Castlereagh, and began the Note itself— Answered the Letter from Mr Schwabe, and accepted, the invitation to attend the meeting of the school Society next Monday. Went with Mrs Adams into Town, and dined with Mrs Porter, a Scotch widow Lady— The company were, Lord St Helen’s; Mr Liston, the British Ambassador at Constantinople, now here on a leave of absence—and his Lady; Mr Aust, formerly an Under-Secretary of State in the foreign Department and his Lady, a third wife, many years younger than himself—Mr and Mrs King; Mr Gracie; and a Mr Boswell, a brother of Dr Johnson’s friend and biographer. Mr and Mrs Liston were several years in America, while my father was President, and well acquainted with my father and mother— Lord St Helen’s had also been acquainted with my father at Paris in the year 1782. He was then Mr Alleyne Fitzherbert, and as the British Plenipotentiary
negotiated the Treaties of Peace with France and Spain. He also signed the article regulating the cessation of hostilities with the American Plenipotentiaries. Mr Liston and his Lady are going immediately on a visit to Scotland— After dinner we went and spent an hour, with Mr and Mrs King at their Lodgings. I gave him one of the Tickets for the meeting of the School Society next Monday.— Home at one in the Morning.

10. VII:30. Engaged all the morning upon the Note to Lord Castlereagh— This was fixed for the second performance of Mr Bibby at Covent-Garden theatre; and he had solicited earnestly our attendance to give him countenance— Mr King who has taken a most ardent interest in his favour, inspired us with some of his zeal, and though I could ill spare the time I was persuaded to go, and to take all the family with me— The three eldest daughters of Dr Nicholas had been invited by Mrs Adams, and were inclined to go— They went with Mrs Adams and our sons John & Charles in the Carriage— We dined at 3. O’Clock, and George and I went in the Stage from Brentford to London. Walked from Piccadilly to Craven Street, and thence with Mr Smith to Covent-Garden— The Plays were the Merchant of Venice, in which Bibby performed the part of Shylock; and Love à la Mode, in which he was Sir Archy M’Sarcasm.— Between the two was a stupid occasional Pageant, called the Royal Nuptials, or the Masque of Hymen, in honour as the Bills announced of the late joyful occasion— The house was very thin; and even at the half-play did not nearly fill up— This was the most unequivocal proof of poor Bibby’s failure of success, notwithstanding all the exertions of his friends King and Delafield, aided by all our countenance which to be sure scarcely filled a single Box— The performances went off heavily— Bibby is in truth what they call here, a respectable performer— But there is no striking or extraordinary merit in him. He has little experience of the Stage, and might perhaps improve into a great actor, which now he is not— He made great efforts; even too great, particularly in Shylock, for he overstrained his voice, and made himself hoarse. But he failed in the general effect; and although there were few particular passages in which his action or delivery could be censured, yet he certainly did not give the perfect image of the Jew’s Passions or of his humour. His Sir Archy was a repetition of his Sir Pertinax, though his Scotch was more intelligible this time— He was applauded in both parts enough and more than enough— There was always, a slight, but portentous hissing heard amidst the clapping by which it was overpowered— He was supported by the other performers, as well as could be expected under the discouragement of a half empty house— The Irish personage in the Man of the World was the most indifferent character— I had as little amusement this Evening, as on the first Night of Bibby’s performance— They were both Evening’s of anxiety and concern for a young Man, who I was convinced from the beginning had undertaken more than he could go through. The two Mr White’s and another young American, were in our box, and in the course of the Evening, Mr Delafield, Mr William Vaughan and Coll Aspinwall came in— The Coll told me, he had received Letters from Mr Shaler, our Consul at Algiers, from Commodore Shaw, and from Mr M’Call, Consul at Barcelona, from which it appears that our Peace with Algiers has turned out as might have been expected— We have been made the dupes of the Barbarians, and must fight it over with them again— Shaler has made a temporary arrangement, by which the Dey has agreed to wait for the final determination of the President of the United States, upon his new demands— Commodore Shaw says that he has a force sufficient to protect our Commerce in the Mediterranean— Coll: Aspinwall thought it might be best not to publish these papers, as they might have the effect of raising the price of insurance— I could not form an opinion without seeing the Letters which he promised to send me to-morrow. The Play was over about Midnight.— The Ladies with my sons John and Charles, returned home; and George and I went and lodged at Craven Street— I received there a Letter from Mr Ingraham the Consul at Plymouth, with a large packet containing the vouchers of his Accounts for expenditures to relieve distressed American Seamen— Also a duplicate of the Letter from Governor Nicholas of Virginia.

11. VII:30. After breakfasting with Mr Smith, George and I walked home. We were overtaken with a shower of rain as we came through St: James’s Park, and stood about twenty minutes, under the shelter of the Porter’s lodge, at Hyde-Park Corner— This made us precisely three hours from the Office in Craven-Street to my own door. It was past one O’Clock when we got home, and we found Mrs Adams, and the boys at Breakfast— After dinner they returned to school— I was employed until dinner time with the Note to Lord Castlereagh; and by the Evening Post received several Letters— From my dear Mother, one of 7. April. communicating the death of Mr William Smith of Boston, and of Mr Justus B. Smith of New-York— From W. Shaler, Consul General at Algiers, dated 14. April, and containing an account of the new difficulties which have arisen there— Lord Exmouth it seems arrived at Algiers on the first of April, with six Line of Battle ships, two frigates, and several Brigs and Transports, and made a peace there for Naples and Sardinia, with Tribute, Ransom, Consular Presents &c &c— Commodore Shaw with three frigates and two Sloops arrived there on the 3d. the day Lord Exmouth’s Treaties were concluded, and immediately our difficulties began— Shaler went on board our Squadron, and there with the white flag flying made an arrangement, without the slightest concession, by which things are to remain on the footing of our Treaty of last June, until the determination of our Government can be received. Shaler says he regards our relations with Algiers as on the footing of a truce; but he does not say what the difficulties are— His Letter is forwarded from Marseilles 30. April, by the Consul and Navy Agent there, Stephen Cathalan, and had been brought there by the frigate United States, Commodore Shaw— From R. W. Fox, Consul at Falmouth, about the Baltimore and her Crew, and about his Accounts— From Thomas Auldjo formerly Consul of the United States at Cowes in the Isle of Wight, mentioning that Coll Aspinwall had informed him that I had been instructed to settle the old Consular Accounts, and enquiring whether his were included in the number, and from John Philips the Kilmarnock man, tendering to me again his “new sistom of sailing” and wondering why he had not received an answer to his former Letter— About nine O’Clock in the Evening, Mr J. A. Smith’s black Servant John came out on horseback, with two Notes from Lord Castlereagh— One referring
referring to the letter from Messrs: Abel and Co. respecting the indirect Trade to India, of which I sent him a copy, and acquainting me, that a Bill will be submitted to Parliament, to allow Vessels of the United States to clear out from any Port of this Kingdom, for any of the principal British Settlements in the East-Indies— The other, requesting me to call upon him at his house in St: James’s Square, to-morrow Morning at half past eleven.

12. VI:15. Finished the Note to Lord Castlereagh concerning the sales of Slaves; upon which I have been so long employed— My wife is making a copy of it; and I took the Press copy with me, for Smith to make out the original Note to be sent. I went to London in the Curricle, after an early Breakfast alone, and at eleven O’Clock was at Lord Castlereagh’s door— I was shewn into the anti-room, and within five minutes, Lord Melville, the first Lord of the Admiralty came in. He told me that they had not yet received any despatches from Mr Bagot— Not even of his arrival at Washington.— But they had Letters from the Captain of the Niger; from Bermuda; to which Island she proceeded after having landed Mr Bagot and his family at Annapolis— I said to Lord Melville in the tone between jest and earnest that I heard Lord Exmouth had been making Peace for Naples and Sardinia, and a quarrel for us, with the Dey of Algiers— He said that was the subject upon which Lord Castlereagh had requested to see me this Morning. They had no intention to make a quarrel between us and Algiers; and hoped no such consequence would follow— I replied that if it should, the quarrel would I hope be rather useful to us than otherwise; and My Lord, said I, if we had only for three years, one third of your naval force, I assure you, that the Christian world should never more hear of tribute, ransom or Slavery to the African Barbarians— Just then the servant came, and ushered us in to Lord Castlereagh’s cabinet. He began immediately upon the subject, and told me that he had asked this interview for the purpose of communicating to me confidentially their Instructions to Lord Exmouth and his proceedings under them, with a view to satisfy the Government of the United States that the conduct of the British Government in these transactions had been fair and honourable; and that although there was one Article of the Treaty between the United States and Algiers, which Great-Britain considered as objectionable it had not been at-all noticed or referred to in Lord Exmouth’s Negotiation— He then read to me two papers and gave me to peruse three others, serving to elucidate all the proceedings of this Government in this affair. They were 1. A Letter from himself to Earle Bathurst, directing by an order of the Cabinet Council, that Instructions from the Lords of the Admiralty should be sent to Lord Exmouth to go and notify to the Barbary Powers, the dispositions by which the allied European Sovereigns have placed the Ionian Islands under the protection of Great Britain; to obtain the acknowledgment of these dispositions; and at the same time to negotiate a Peace between the Barbary Powers and the kingdoms of the two Sicilies and of Sardinia. The motives alledged for this measure are, the obligations of Great-Britain to extend to the Ionian Islands since they have been made a part of the British dominions, the same privileges enjoyed in the Mediterranean seas, by other British subjects—the general indignation arising throughout Europe, against the mode of warfare practised by the Barbary States against Christians; and the urgent applications of the king’s two intimate allies the kings of Naples and Sardinia; more particularly a very recent one from the latter of these Sovereigns, through his Minister at this Court, for the interposition of Great-Britain to effect this Peace in respect to his dominions— It is observed that by the annexation of Genoa to the Sardinian Dominions the importance to them of a Peace with the Barbary States had increased. That the object of that annexation having been to strengthen the barrier on the side of Italy against France, it would be more consonant with that policy that all the resources of Sardinia should be applied to its military power by Land, than that any part of them should be diverted to the purpose of making it a naval power— That while the Island of Malta had been possessed by the knights of that order, they had been at perpetual war with the Barbary Powers, and had thereby afforded considerable protection to the Commerce of the Mediterranean States against their Cruizers. And as Great-Britain now possessed Malta, although she was not obliged to take upon her the duty of protecting all the Christian flags, the revenues of the Order, not having been transferred to her, yet it was proper she should exercise her influence of protection to a certain extent. 24 [symbols] Lord Exmouth was therefore to be instructed to go to Algiers, Tunis and Tripoli; and to perswade their Governments to make a Peace with Naples and Sardinia, upon the footing of that with Portugal. He was to agree that the same rate of ransom as had heretofore been paid for prisoners, Subjects of those Powers, should be paid for those he should find there in captivity. And that the usual presents in money should hereafter be paid for them. He was to resist & reject all demands for contributions of naval or military Stores, and to require the release without ransom, of all prisoners, natives of the Ionian Islands. But although he was to refuse any stipulated compensation for their deliverance, he was authorized
to give it to be understood that a suitable present would be made for them. He was also to admonish the Regencies of the rising indignation of Europe against their mode of warfare; and to advise them to abandon it, and to resort to more creditable resources for the support of their Governments. At the same time he was to assure them of the friendly disposition of Great-Britain towards them, and that she would not support any Christian State in any unjust claim or pretension against them— He was in the first instance to urge all this in an amicable manner; but was explicitly authorised to use force if necessary— 2. A second Letter from Lord Castlereagh to Earle Bathurst dated 13. March. stating that the Treaty between the United States of America and Algiers, concluded on the 30th. of June 1815. and ratified at Washington, on the 26th. of December last, had engaged the attention of His Majesty’s Government That the 18th. Article in particular, would in the case of a future War between Great-Britain, and the United-States, be incompatible with the 9th. and 10th: Articles of the Treaty of 1698. between Great-Britain and Algiers, which had been recognized and renewed in all the subsequent Treaties between them. That it might not for this reason be necessary to require the abrogation of the Treaty, between the United States and Algiers, but that Lord Exmouth should be instructed formally to protest against the Application of that Article of the Treaty, to Great-Britain in the case of any future hostilities between this Country and the United States. 3. A Report from Lord Exmouth, dated 17. April at Tunis, to the Lords of the Admiralty, of his Execution of the first Instructions at Algiers and at Tunis. He states that he had not received the second Instructions (those relative to the Treaty between the United States and Algiers) until after he had left Algiers, and that he should therefore execute them upon his return. 4. A Summary Statement of the Terms upon which the Peace was concluded, both at Algiers, and at Tunis, for Sardinia and for Naples. The Ransom for the Sardinian Prisoners was 500 dollars for each man, and for the Neapolitans 1000. The Consular and other Presents in future to be as usual heretofore, but only in money. The Ionian Islanders to be restored without ransom. 5. A Declaration by Mahmoud Bashaw, Bey of Tunis, addressed to Lord Exmouth, and promising, in Consideration of the anxious desire manifested by His Royal Highness the Prince Regent of England, to put an end to the Slavery of Christians, and to prove his esteem for the European Powers, and his pacific disposition, that in case of War with any of the said Powers, the prisoners shall not be reduced to Slavery; but treated as Prisoners of War, and at the end of the War exchanged and sent home— After thanking Lord Castlereagh for the communication of these Documents, the purport of which I assured him I should immediately report to the Government of the United States, I told him that as the Instructions to Lord Exmouth had positively forbidden him to stipulate for any future contributions to the Barbarians in naval or military Stores, I hoped that in the next arrangement, which Great-Britain should make with them for her friends she would proceed one step further and prohibit the payment to them of money, which was equivalent to, and would procure them all. And as the Prince Regent’s anxiety to put an end to Christian Slavery had obtained a Declaration from the Bay of Tunis, that he would no longer reduce Christian Prisoners to Slavery, the same influence would here after be exerted, effectually to abolish that practice on the part of all the Barbary Powers, and especially Algiers. That it was worthy of Great-Britain, to take the lead in the abolition of this species of Slavery, as she had done with regard to that of the Africans. That she was perfectly able to accomplish it alone, and in that case would enjoy all the credit and glory of having effected it. But if she preferred to have the co-operation of others, I was confident she might rely upon that of the United States, to the full proportion of their Power, and that I thought her having succeeded to the possession of the Island of Malta really did impose upon her the obligation of affording to the Christian Commerce, at least all the protection that it could derive from the perpetual War between that order and the Infidels. Lord Castlereagh declared that it was the earnest wish of the British Government, that all the Barbary Powers should abandon altogether this mode of warfare; but he thought that mild and moderate measures, and persuasion would be better calculated to produce this effect than force. He seemed even to consider that this payment of money to them would have the tendency of relaxing them into good humour, and incline them to compliance with the wish that they would make no more Slaves to be ransomed. He said that although Great-Britain possessed the Island of Malta, she had none of the Revenues, which had been assigned by all the principal States of Europe to the Order. That Great-Britain with all her exertions had not been able to obtain the abolition of the African Slave-trade by Spain and Portugal, and as she would not have felt justified in resorting to War, to compel them to it, so she could not make War upon the Barbary States to force them to renounce the practice of making Slaves of Christians, so long as they never applied it to her Subjects, or had given her any cause of offence. It was for other Powers to vindicate and maintain the Liberties of their own People; and besides the Northern Maritime States France, Spain and all those who had possessions on the Mediterranean had as strong an obligation to put down the scandal of Christian Slavery, as Great-Britain. She had for herself no complaint against the Barbary States to make— She had often found them useful friends; and especially during the late War in the Peninsula, which it would have been impossible for her to have carried through successfully without the supplies
which her troops had received from the coast of Barbary—from which they had almost all their fresh provisions. Great-Britain however had no interest or desire to countenance or encourage the Wars of the Barbary States against the other navigating European Powers. She had no unworthy policy of securing by such means an exclusive privilege to her own flag, of securely navigating in the Mediterranean Seas— But she did not think that the obligation of putting an end to the depredations of the Barbary States was incumbent upon her alone; and if it was to be effected, she thought the best mode of accomplishing it would be by convincing them that it would be better for their own interest to resort to other, and more honest sources of Prosperity.— I observed that as to the manner of accomplishing the object, if Great-Britain would undertake it, that must be at her own option. There could not be supposed any necessity for her resorting to the use of force.— The intimation of her will, and the exhibition of her means of enforcement, would infallibly be as efficacious upon the Dey of Algiers, as the Prince Regent’s wish had been upon the Bey of Tunis. As to the assistance which had been derived from supplies of Provisions to the British Troops in Spain, the interest of the Seller was doubtless the motive for that, and it could lay no claim to the merit of an obligation. If however, Great-Britain should not incline to assume the task of putting an end to Barbary Piracy, if she would leave them in our hands, I believed we should be able to give a good account of them. The experience of the last year had proved that they were not very formidable antagonists upon the Ocean, and if we had to deal with them alone; I had no doubt that our navy would be competent to the protection of our Commerce against them. I was not informed what the precise point of difference between Algiers and us now was; but as to the conflicting Articles of the two Treaties there could be no difficulty in an arrangement between the two Governments concerning it— He replied that we might depend upon meeting no molestation, in our operations, against Algiers, on the part of Great-Britain— He thought that the place itself could not be attacked with any prospect of success— There had been of late years a change in the system of Algerine warfare, which had been to their own disadvantage. Formerly they had been accustomed to send out small gallies, and xebecs, and gunboats for shallow waters, which cost nothing, and against which it was scarcely possible to protect commercial vessels, especially during certain Seasons of the year. Of late they had undertaken to maintain a sort of Navy— Large, expensive frigates, with which they had effected their descents on the Coasts of Italy and Sardinia, and carried off whole villages. But such vessels were not so well adapted to the annoyance of Commerce as those which they had formerly employed— The large ships could be out only part of the year, and then they could neither fight, nor navigate them well.— Defence against them would not be difficult; but it was Lord Exmouth’s opinion, that if they should resort again to their old system, there could be no effectual protection for merchant vessels against them through all Seasons— This was the substance of the Conversation, in which Lord Melville took none, or scarcely any part—appearing merely to assent to the observations of Lord Castlereagh.— Before leaving them I mentioned to Lord Castlereagh, the not that I addressed to him the first of this month, concerning, the American vessel refused entry at Liverpool, because the Collector at Richmond certified that the master had been qualified, instead, of saying sworn, to manifest of tobacco: I told him that in some parts of the United States, I knew the term qualified was used, and received as equivalent to sworn— Lord Melville said that sometimes it was so used in this Country— Lord Castlereagh had not seen, or had forgotten, my Note; but he promised to enquire after it. I also told Lord Castlereagh that I had received Instructions to ask for a permission to export Rollers, for the use of the Mint of the United States— He said there could be no difficulty in that; but Lord Melville remarked that the prohibition was by Act of Parliament. Lord Castlereagh asked me to write him a note about it— I had ordered the Coachman to come with the Curricle for me to Craven Street at five O’Clock— I walked from Lord Castlereagh’s to my Office, and there found Mr M. C. Paterson with Mr Smith. I also received there a Letter from Coll: Aspinwall, enclosing those to him from Mr Shaler, Commodore Shaw, and Mr M’Call, the navy Agent, and Consul at Barcelona, relating to our new troubles with Algiers. Coll: Aspinwall has doubts as to the expediency of publishing the information they contain and asks my opinion of it— He sends me likewise a Letter from Mr: G. W. Erving at Havre dated the 5th: of this month— Bound to Paris, and as Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to Spain. He sailed from New-York the 10th. of April, and gives me the recent news from America— At half past three O’Clock, I left the Office, and walked home in two hours and twenty Minutes, the shortest time I have ever taken for it and walking the whole way at the rate of four miles an hour— My usual rate of walking is 3 1/2 miles an hour— I was twice overtaken with heavy showers of hail, Sleet, and Snow—the first in Hyde Park, and the second at Turnham Green.— The last soaked me through and through, so that on reaching home I was obliged to change my clothing— I had also blistered one of my feet— George went this Evening to Church at Brentford.— I also received at the Office, a printed notification from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office, of a Court Mourning of three
weeks, for the late Empress of Austria—to commence this day— Full Mourning a fortnight— Half Mourning, a week— And a written Notice from the same office, that there will be a Levee at Carleton House next Tuesday, and a Drawing Room at the Queen’s Palace, next Thursday, both at two O’Clock.

13. VI. Wrote before Breakfast a short Letter to my Mother— Went with Mrs Adams to London; took up at Craven-Street Mr J. A. Smith, and attended the Meeting of the British and foreign School-Society, 1 [symbols] at the London Tavern, Bishopsgate Street. The Meeting was appointed for twelve O’Clock, the Chair to be taken precisely at One— It was near one when we arrived— They were waiting for the Duke of Kent who was to preside. The Lord Mayor was there, but he was engaged to go with an address from the Common Council, to the Prince of Saxe-Coburg, and the Princess Charlotte— It was agreed therefore, that the Lord Mayor should take the Chair to open the Meeting, and immediately resign it to Lord Darnley, who should preside until the Duke should come— All this was arranged in the Committee Room, into which I was introduced, and where I knew not a Soul excepting the Lord Mayor.— I followed the Company into the Hall which was crowded with a numerous auditory, and took my seat upon the Platform— The Lord Mayor opened the meeting; apologized that he was obliged to go to change his dress and go in the old State waggon to Camelford House; but said that he would leave the Lady Mayoress to supply his place, and Lord Darnley would take the Chair until the Duke of Kent should come. Lord Darnley accordingly took the Chair for a few minutes until the Duke arrived. He apologized for being late, and said that his Carriage had been detained 25 minutes, at a place in the city where the Street had been so obstructed by other Carriages & waggons that he could not get along— The Report of the Treasurer of the Society was then read; and immediately afterwards a written motion was put into my hand with a request that I would move it— It was marked N. 1.—His Excellency the American Ambassador will move—That the “Report which has now been read be received and adopted, and that it be printed under the direction of the Committee—To be seconded by—[”] I had suspected that they would call upon me, for some address, motion or speech; but not that I should have been summoned out the very first; and I was not a little embarrassed what to say— The Duke of Kent however in calling upon me to make the motion, relieved me from much of my aukwardness; by observing that the Report just read had been very long, that the time remaining to transact the business to be done was short; and that he requested all those who proposed to address the Company to be as brief in their remarks as possible— I said—“Mindful of that admonition which has just been so properly given by His Royal Highness the illustrious chairman of this Meeting, I shall not a waste a moment of your time, in commenting upon the Report which you have just heard— I am sensible that no encomium of mine can add grace or dignity to that Spirit of benevolence, which walks abroad, communicating wisdom and virtue (for Education in wisdom and virtue) wherever it goes— To enlarge upon it, would in me be presumption; for I am well assured that I could utter nothing in its praise, which has not already been anticipated in every bosom of those whom I have now the honour to address— One remark only I may be permitted to make, in reference to that passage of the Report, in which honourable notice is taken of my native Country, for the ardour and zeal with which it promotes, and encourages Institutions devoted to the purposes of Education— It would certainly not become me to question the accuracy of this compliment, or to detract from the merit which may be ascribed to my Country for it. I shall only say that it would be utterly impossible for a Nation descended from British Ancestry, to be neglectful of the Education of their Children—” I then made the motion, which was seconded, and adopted. A number of other motions were successively made, and passed; and the meeting was addressed in Speeches; by Lord Darnley; the Revd: Rowland Hill, a Methodist Clergyman—the Revd: Mr Lindsay a dissenting Minister, Mr Schwabe the foreign Secretary of the Society, and some others. From their Speeches I collected that this Institution is viewed with Jealousy by the Established Church; and that their favour is confined to a rival institution, where the benefits of Education are bestowed only upon Children bred upon the principles of the Establishment.— Count Lieven the Russian Ambassador was to have been present but sent an excuse— But there was present a Mr Balk-Oleff, who is going out as Minister from the Emperor of Russia to Brazil, who was requested to make one of the motions, and who made it by proxy— A gentleman spoke for him, and expressed for him his regret that his acquaintance with the English language was not sufficient to enable him to speak in public himself. The last vote; being N. 9. was to have been moved by some other person; but from what cause I know not, they brought it to me. It was thus—N. 9. . . . will move . . . That the thanks of this Meeting be presented to His Royal Highness the Duke of Kent, for his unremitting exertion, in the cause of this Institution, and for his able conduct in presiding at this Meeting—to be seconded by— But I did not wait for a second— I said, Ladies and Gentlemen— The motion which I have now to present to you, is one, which I have as high and sincere pride and gratification in being permitted to make, as I am sure you will unanimously take in adopting it— I then read the motion and put the question upon which the whole auditory rose and held up their hands— The Duke answered the vote by an Address, in which he declared his warm attachment to the Institution, and his good wishes for its success— His satisfaction at the crowded and respectable appearance of the Meeting, which he had appointed to be held there, in the East part of Town, from a conviction that a most liberal collection for the benevolent purposes of the Society would be made there— He felt the greater satisfaction too at the respectability of the meeting, as this was the last time he should have the opportunity of giving his attendance on the like occasion for several, he could not say how many years— He was shortly to leave the Country, to reside some years upon the Continent— And when the objects for which he should thus absent himself should be accomplished, he now pledged himself to give one thousand guineas to this Institution— If he had not given them before, it was not because the will, but because the means had been wanting.— It gave him peculiar satisfaction
that the motion of thanks to him had been made by the Minister of the United States, a Country in the neighbourhood of which he had several years resided, which had his best wishes for its prosperity; and the unfortunate differences with which had always given him great pain and concern.— He concluded by appealing to the liberality of the meeting to contribute to the funds of the Society, and observed that the Lady Mayoress, and Lady Darnley would hold the plates at the door— The meeting then dissolved, and we took Miss B. Vaughan home, to her brother’s house N. 1. Dunster Court, Mincing Lane— A house, where I have known him, and experienced his hospitable friendship from November 1783— We returned thence to Craven-Street; and the Carriage requiring some repairs, dined there— I had written last Friday a Note to William Couling, asking him to call this day at my Office, he accordingly came— I read to him the Letter, from the Governor of Virginia, enquiring upon what terms a civil engineer could be procured to be employed under the directions of the Legislature of that State— I told Couling, I had thought he was exactly the person they wanted, and that their business was exactly what he wanted; and asked him if he would undertake it, and upon what terms— He said it was exactly what he wanted; and in a very few days he would state to me the terms upon which he would go, though he was willing to leave them to the liberality of the Governor of Virginia— He said he would also bring me a statement of the works in which he had been engaged; and some samples of his drawings and Surveys— I also received a Letter from Mr Russell, at Stockholm; and a Note from the Chevalier de Freire enclosing Packets for the Portuguese Minister and Consul General in the United States; to be forwarded— Immediately after dinner, we called on Mr: and Mrs: C King, at their lodgings in Conduit Street. Mr King concluded to be presented at Court, and will attend at the Levee to-morrow. We got home at 9. P.M.

14. VI:30. I answered this morning Coll: Aspinwall’s Letter of the 11th. instant; returned him the Letters from Mr Shaler, Commodore Shaw and Mr M’Call, and recommended to him to publish the information contained in them.— Answered also the Letter from George and James Abel, of 20. April concerning the clearing of American vessels, direct to the British Ports in India. I went into London, and attended the Prince Regent’s Levee at Carleton House— I presented to him, Mr J. A. Smith, as the Secretary of Legation, and Mr Charles King— The usage is to give Cards, with the names of the persons, to be presented, to the Lord in waiting; but Mr King had forgotten to take his Card with him, and I was obliged to write his name on the back of Mr Smith’s Card, which I gave to the Lord in waiting— But the presentations were so numerous, that the Lord in waiting after presenting Mr Smith, forgot to turn the card, and the Prince was passing on, when I presented Mr King to him myself— The Prince spoke to him in handsome terms of his father; the crowd at the Levee was very great— The Dukes of York, Clarence, Kent and Gloucester, and the Prince of Coburg were there— I also met Mr Thornton now the British Minister in Sweden, and whom I had seen in 1803. as the Chargé d’Affaires at Washington. I did not recognize him, until I heard him named; nor he me, until I spoke to him— Mr Liston was also there, and told me that he should leave town the day after to-morrow for Bath, and Scotland— When the entrée Levee was over, and the door for the great Levee was opened, the stream began, and we stood observing the persons as they passed, an hour and a half; and we withdrew before it was exhausted.— As we were coming out I met Captain Forbes, who had been with Lord Cathcart, at St: Petersburg— He is now attached to the British Ambasy at Vienna, and told me he expected to leave town in a very few days to go there— I took Mr King home to his lodgings, and then returned to Craven Street to undress— I received a Note from Mr Chester, the Assistant Master of Ceremonies, enclosing a Copy of a Notification he had received from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office; that the Queen will hold a Drawing Room, at her Palace the day after to-morrow at 2. O’Clock; and that the Court will not appear in Mourning on this occasion, it being a Drawing Room to receive Congratulations upon the Marriage of Her Royal Highness the Princess Charlotte Augusta, with His Serene Highness Leopold George Frederick Duke of Saxe, Margrave of Meissen Landgrave of Thuringuen, Prince of Cobourg of Saalfeld— It enclosed also a ticket for my Carriage to enter at Constitution Hill on Thursday— I wrote him a Note requesting a similar ticket, for Mr King’s Carriage, which at the Levee he had promised he would send me. I received also at the Office, Letters from J Clarke, artist in Fireworks; asking a subscription, with the other Foreign Ambassadors &c. for an exhibition of Fireworks, in honour of the late Royal Marriage; with four tickets at half a guinea each, and a subscription list of the names of most of the foreign Ministers, and subscriptions of two and three guineas each—from James Brown, a Man who came to me last Summer, immediately after my arrival in London, and left pamphlets and Manuscript papers, and proposals from naval officers, to enter the service of the United States. He now writes in great distress; and asks for relief, and the return of his Papers— From Coll. Aspinwall, with information that the extra port charges of foreign shipping continue to be levied upon American Vessels in the Port of London— From G. Hippisley referring to the Letter to Captain Trenchard, which he sent me, last December; enquiring whether it was speedily forwarded, and when he may expect an answer; and informing me that it concerned a son of Mr Hippisley’s, who
has been a British naval officer, and desires to enter the Service of the United States— From R. W. Fox, Consul at Falmouth, a long Letter, concerning the Seamen of the Baltimore; and from Gustavus M. Ware, one of those Seamen; again imploring assistance and relief. I sent the Coachman with the Carriage, to the Coachmaker’s Messer and Page, for the new set of wheels. It is to be ready with them on Thursday Morning— They sent a Chariot for use until then in its stead— I came home with it, about eight o’clock in the Evening.

15. VII. I wrote to the Secretary of State, Despatch N. 44. enclosing Copies of the Note last received from Lord Castlereagh, concerning the sales of Slaves by British Officers in the West-Indies, and of my answer to it, which I sent to Lord Castlereagh yesterday— 10 [symbols] Received Letters—from T. Dickason and Co. requesting me to apply to the Spanish Ambassador, and request him to demand by a Note to the Secretary of State for foreign Affairs, restitution of the William and Mary and her Cargo.— But he has already made this demand— From Reuben Shapley of Portsmouth New-Hampshire, stating a claim that he has against the British Government, for a vessel taken, after the period fixed for the Cessation of hostilities, and lost. He says the papers of the case, have been forwarded to me by Mr Monroe, the Secretary of State, to be laid before the British Government; but I have not received them— I walked before dinner to Ealing and Gunnersbury.

16. VI:15. Answered the Letter yesterday received from T. Dickason and Co.—and one received on the 7th. instant from James Holmes at Newry; Ireland— Immediately after Breakfast we went to London.— I walked as far as Kew-Bridge when Mrs Adams overtook me in the Carriage— I alighted at Hyde Park Corner, and walked to the Office in Craven Street— She went to dress, at Mrs King’s lodgings; to send home the Chariot to the Coachmaker’s; from whence the Coachman came with our own Carriage, and took me up with Mr Smith at Craven Street— We went to Mr King’s and took there Mrs Adams— Mr King followed in his own carriage; we attended the Queen’s Drawing Room. We reached the Palace, of Buckingham house, in very good season, at half past one O’Clock— Precisely at two the Doors of the chamber where the Queen was, were thrown open, for the foreign Ambassadors, and Ministers; and we were among the first that passed— The Queen was sitting in a chair— The Princesses Augusta, Elizabeth, Mary, the Princess Charlotte of Wales, and the Princess Sophia of Gloucester were standing, at her right hand in a sort of semicircle, at sufficient distances from each other to leave space for their hoops— The Prince of Coburg stood at the window, behind the Princess Sophia— The Duke of Sussex was there; but went away before the Prince Regent came— The Dukes of York, Clarence, Kent, and Gloucester were also there— And from two O’Clock until five the stream of persons passing before the Queen never ceased to flow— The Antichambers, the Stair-case, all the Rooms on the lower floor, were so excessively crowded, that many of the Gentlemen in their full dresses and of Ladies in their hoops were obliged to stand for hours, on the green, in front of the Palace, before they could get admission within the doors. There were it was said three thousand persons there— I presented to the Queen, Mr J. A. Smith, as the Secretary of the American Legation; and Mr Charles King, whom she remembered to have seen at Harrow School— I gave their Cards before presenting them, to the Earl of Morton, the Queen’s chamberlain who stood at her left hand. The Prince Regent came about four O’Clock— The crowd and the heat were so great that several of the Ladies fainted— I introduced Mr Smith to Lady Castlereagh, who invited him to her evening parties on Saturdays after the Opera— She told me she had mentioned them to Mrs Adams; but supposed it might be inconvenient to us, to come in, so far from the country— I spoke to Lord Castlereagh, about the Algerine affairs— Mentioned the motion said to have been lately made in the French house of Peers, by the Vicomte de Chateaubriand—which was, that the king of France should be requested to instruct his Ambassadors at the different Courts of Europe, to propose that they should all unite in the endeavour to prevail upon the Barbary Powers, to abolish their practice of making slaves of Christians.— I enquired if any proposal of that sort had been made by the French Ambassador here— He said there had not; and with a sneering smile, added that he thought it was only a project of Sir Sidney Smith’s, which would not meet with much encouragement— We came away just before the Drawing-Room closed. It was with the utmost difficulty that we made our way down the Stair-case; and at the door we were stopped to make way for the Princess Charlotte and her husband; and after them, for the Duchess of York to go. We reached at length our Carriages; went and left Mrs Adams at Mrs King’s, and returned to Craven Street— Mr William Cranch Bond called on me there— He has been spending the winter with his relations in Devonshire; and is now about returning to America.— He brought several drawings that he has made, of Observatories, at various places in this Country— I returned to Conduit Street and took up Mrs Adams and Lucy— Mr and Mrs King were gone to dine at Mr W. Vaughan’s at East-Hill, Wandsworth— Mrs Adams made a party to meet them on Saturday at Windsor— Mr Gracie, and Mr Bibby were at Mr King’s, Bibby has not succeeded in obtaining an engagement at Covent-Garden theatre— It was about half past seven when we got home— Mr King had given me the National Intelligencer of 12. April, containing the Act of Congress for establishing a Bank of the United States.

17. VI. The dissipation of yesterday, left its usual traces of ineptitude to studious application this morning, which I therefore amused by reading the Act for establishing the new Bank of the United States; after which I wrote a Letter to my brother— This was all the occupation of the day— Before dinner I walked to Gunnersbury and Ealing; and after dinner in our Garden; but the Evening was so cold that we were soon obliged to return into the house again.

18. VI: Mrs Adams and our three Sons went to Windsor; to meet Mr and Mrs King, and their party there. I could not spare the time to go with them, for besides the arrears of my Journal, which already pass three weeks, those of my correspondence are very considerable,
and I had not yet made to the Secretary of State the report of my conference, with Lord Castlereagh, and Lord Melville, last Sunday. This was a Subject of too much importance to admit of longer postponement; so that I adjourned my visit to Windsor, and my wife and Children went without me. I was engaged all day upon the despatch to the Secretary of State N. 45. which I did not finish. While writing it, I perceived there were several particulars, especially of dates upon which my memory was not confident. I therefore wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh, requesting copies of the Papers which he shewed and read to me last Sunday if they could be furnished me, without inconvenience— I walked before dinner to Hanwell and Ealing—dined alone; and amused the Evening by the perusal of the latest American Newspapers that have come to hand— Received Letters from—James Maury, Consul at Liverpool, enclosing his account of expenditures for the relief of distressed American Seamen—from R. G. Beasley, dated yesterday, mentioning that he should leave town in the Evening, to go and embark at Liverpool for the United States; and that he had ordered two leather Trunks, and a Letter Box, the property of the United States, to be sent to my Office—from J. A. Smith, enclosing a Letter from Jenner, Bush and Jenner, Procters at Doctor’s Commons, to Greg Lindsay & Co. concerning the case of the Nanina; and requesting my intervention with the Government. This Letter was left at my Office, by Mr Walker, of the House of Greg, Lindsay and Co.—from Dr: Charles Taylor Secretary to the Society of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce, enclosing two tickets for the anniversary dinner of the Society on the 27th: of this Month, and an invitation to attend at the annual distribution of the premiums and bounties voted by the Society, which is to take place on the 31st: instant, and for which Dr Taylor offers to furnish any number of tickets that I may desire. 11 [symbols]

19. VI. Attended Church at Ealing. Prayers were read for the fifth Sunday after Easter; and the Sermon preached by Mr Millman from 1. Corinthians XI:31. “For if we would judge ourselves, we should not be judged.” It was the second part of a Discourse, the former part of which had been delivered this day fortnight week, the day that I was in London, and a continuation of the Treatise against slander, commenced upon another text, the 28th. of last Month— I finished my despatch to the Secretary of State, and wrote short Letters to my Mother and to President Kirkland, to send by Mr Bond. My wife and three Sons, returned from Windsor, where they missed of meeting Mr and Mrs King— Mr M. C. Paterson, Mr W. C. Bond, and Mr J. A. Smith came out and dined with us— In the Evening, John and Charles returned to School.— Received a Letter from G. & J. Abel, in reply to mine of the 14th instant to them, and making further enquiries as to the construction and effect of the Convention of 3. July 1815.

20. VI: Answered the Letter, yesterday received from George and James Abel; and the invitation to the anniversary dinner of the Society of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce— Wrote also to R. G. Beasley at Liverpool, enclosing the Letters to my Mother; and brother— Last Evening I received a Letter from S. Williams, enclosing an extract of one, from Joseph Wilson, son and Co. his correspondents at Dublin, complaining of the discrimination between British and American vessels, as to the carrying of Passengers, and requesting him to apply for my interposition with the British Government, to obtain for American vessels, the same privileges enjoyed for British Vessels— But Williams himself hopes, that neither the American nor the British will be allowed to carry more than one Passenger to every five Tons— As he thinks, at that rate more Irishmen will go, than are desired.— And this morning, I received a Letter, from W. A and W. Brown and Co. for their friends W. and Jas Brown and Co. at Liverpool, complaining that the Collector at that Port, refuses to clear out an American vessel for Batavia, unless it can be shewn by any Treaty that that colony has been ceded to the Dutch; or a licence be obtained from the Board of controul, the Secretary of which considers the case of an American vessel, as not within his cognizance— They also request my interference— I went with Mrs Adams into London; and alighting at Craven Street, left her the Carriage to pay several visits, and walked into the City.— First to the Counting House of the Brothers Baring & Co. where I took a check on their Bankers, and left £8. to be placed to the credit of G. W. Erving’s private account, being the payment of Pio’s debt to him— Mr Baring told me that he had received the remittances for the payment of the interest on the Louisiana loan, on the first of July, both here and at Amsterdam.— From thence I went to the Counting house of A. Glennie, Son and Co. where I saw Mr Fry. I spoke to him of the claim in behalf of Mr Kempton of Philadelphia; and enquired what they wished me to do in it— He said the case was now before a judicial Court here upon the appeal— They did not wish for my interposition at present; but will give me notice, whenever they shall think it may be of service— I also mentioned to him the case of the Seamen of the Baltimore; and urged the necessity that their wages should be paid; to prevent their becoming a burden upon the public— But he said the Agents of the owners, at Liverpool had already advanced upon the ship, more money than she was worth—the owners themselves were not responsible persons, and the seamen had forfeited their wages by deserting the ship.— The agents, W. and Jas Brown
would not allow the payment of a penny to them— I next went to Mr S. Williams’s in Finsbury Square; but he was not at home— I then returned to Craven Street; where Mrs Adams soon came; and we returned home— It was past seven when we reached our house— Mrs Adams among her other visits had called on Mrs Bourke, the Danish Minister’s Lady, who enquired if we had received an invitation to the Prince Regent’s Dress Party for to-morrow Evening; and was much surprized on hearing that we had not. She herself had received her invitation yesterday Morning; and her husband Mr Bourke, late last Evening.

21. VI: The continual employment and dissipation of the two last months has been such that my journal has been unavoidably running again in arrears—day has encroached upon day, until it has now amounted within two or three days of a full Month— To preserve the chain of Events, I have been obliged to resort to the expedient of keeping a separate minute; containing an abstract; allotting one line for every day— For a man much overplied with business, this is the best method perhaps of keeping a diary; and it is too probable I shall soon be able to keep no other— From this index, I began this Morning the Journal of the 24th: of April, from which time the arrears are, if possible to be redeemed— Answered also the Letter which I received on the 12th. instant from G. W. Erving.— Had a visit with a subscription paper, from the organist of Ealing Church; and W. Couling came out from London, and brought for my inspection several Plans, and drawings done by him and a statement of the principal works upon which he has been employed. He has not yet settled in his mind the terms, upon which he would wish to be engaged— Said he had sometimes received two guineas a day; but that he could not expect so much for a constancy.
